block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

Lebanese Offer to Deploy Troops Dismissed by Israel Lebanon's government, including two Hezbollah ministers, offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops to the south if Israel withdrew its forces. Israel insisted that its troops would remain until an international force capable of halting Hezbollah missile strikes into Israel is in place. A8

Hezbollah rocket fire in the north of Israel has ignited hundreds of fires in the few forests in the Galilee region. Officials estimated that as much as 3,000 acres of forest has been damaged by fire from the rockets. A9

In Iraq, Striving for a Cool Phone According to the State Department, there are now 7.1 million cellphone subscribers in Iraq. Iraqis of all sects rely on their phones as a means of communication to avoid danger, as well as a means of self-expression. As a status symbol certain phones are given names, like ''Apache,'' and have price tags reaching $800. A1

Cubans Expect Rapid Recovery High-ranking Cuban officials, working hard to put out the message that Cuba is stable after the transfer of power from Fidel Castro to his younger brother, said that Mr. Castro was recovering and that he would be able to return to duty ''in a short time.'' A4

Flood in Ethiopia Kills 191 A flash flood in Dire Dawa, in eastern Ethiopia, swept away houses, factories and dozens of people over the weekend, killing at least 191, with 300 more still missing, officials said. A6
Taiwan Loses Another Ally Taiwan's foreign minister warned that Beijing's establishment of diplomatic relations with Chad, one of Taiwan's few remaining allies, would hurt relations with China. A6
NATIONAL A12-15

Ohio Congressman Will Not Seek Re-election Representative Bob Ney, left, an Ohio Republican entangled in the corruption scandal centered on the former lobbyist Jack Abramoff, announced that he would abandon his bid for re-election.

DeLay to Stay on Ballot The Supreme Court dealt a final blow to efforts by the Texas Republican Party to replace former Representative Tom DeLay on the Congressional ballot in November, leaving him the reluctant party nominee from his longtime district.

Fighting Crime in New Orleans After months of chaos in the criminal justice system, Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans announced the first steps to replace the city's missing prosecutors, public defenders and police officers, along with its ruined courtrooms.

Phoenix Man Claims Innocence One of two men charged in a series of killings in Phoenix told reporters that he was innocent and that his roommate might have taken his car and guns to commit the crimes.
SCIENCE TIMES F1-8

The Seafloor as Gas Trap A team of researchers propose what they say is a limitless, low-risk repository for carbon dioxide, the heat-trapping gas emitted by power plants: seafloor sediments at depths and temperatures that would guarantee the gas would be permanently locked away. F3
Health & Fitness F5
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Senate Rivals Shift Tactics In Last Day of Campaigning As Connecticut voters prepared for their highly anticipated Democratic primary, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Ned Lamont, the rivals for United States Senate, used sharply different tactics in seeking a final advantage in a contest that appeared to be tightening. A1

Audit Faults Fiscal Practices State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, in the latest stinging audit of a Long Island school district, has accused the superintendent of the William Floyd School District of dispensing raises to himself and other administrators, awarding no-bid contracts, and overseeing millions of dollars in ''inappropriate'' expenditures. B1

Brewery Moves to Newark Rolling Rock Beer, a longtime staple of Latrobe in the mountains of western Pennsylvania, will soon begin brewing in the Anheseur-Busch plant on Routes 1 and 9 in the shadow of Newark Liberty International Airport in Newark. B1
SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6

Landis Defends Performance Floyd Landis set out on a vigorous public relations campaign, speaking to about a dozen television stations and newspapers, to declare that he did not use performance-enhancing drugs to win the Tour de France. D3
ARTS E1-10
Foundation Selects New Leader The Barnes Foundation announced that it had appointed a prominent Philadelphia arts figure as its executive director, ending a 14-month search. E1
BUSINESS DAY C1-12

BP Shuts Down Oil Field BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already high world crude oil prices to $77 a barrel.
A1
Pension Plan Shortages Across the nation, states, counties and municipalities may owe their current and future retirees roughly $375 billion more than they have committed to their pension funds.
A1

Google Has MySpace Deal Google won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation. Google promised to pay a minimum of $900 million.
C1
